name: ANDELEYS, Les

name: AVOUZON
notes: NA

name: CHAMPVENT sur YVERDON
notes: NA

name: CHAUMONT en BASSIGNEY
notes: NA

name: CHAUX d'ESTALIERES
notes: Confirmation: Former name for a valley & old mairies incorporating Les Taillères and La Brévine. Dictionnaire Historique de la Suisse. Coordinates as for Les Taillères. For mapping and data analysis reasons, Neuchâtel sovereign territory is 'Neuchâtel' and not 'Prussia'.

name: FONTENOTTES
notes: Confirmation: is Les Fontenottes, 25130 Villers-le-Lac, France, 4 km from Morteau.

name: GLAY sous BLAMONT
notes: NA

name: KIZINGEN
notes: NA

name: MÉLIÈRE
notes: Confirmation: is Meslière or Merslières near Blamont as identified in sources.

name: MEYRIA
notes: Confirmation: identified as 'par Nantua'. Meyria is the old name for a hamlet in the commune of Bohas-Meyriat-Rignat in the Ain close to Nantua.

name: MONTARGIS en Gatinois
notes: NA

name: MOULINNEUF
notes: Confirmation: identified as (close to) Gex.

name: RENAN (Rangée des Robert)
notes: Confirmation: described in source as Renan, (Rangée des Robert).

name: RENAN (Montagne du Droit)
notes: Confirmation: described in source as Renan (Montagne du Droit. Montagne du Droit is between Renan and Sonvilliers.

name: VALENCE en Dauphiné
notes: Higher education: the University was created in 1452 and absorbed the University of Grenoble in 1565/7. It was suppressed in 1793.

name: VRAICHAMP-DOCELLES
notes: NA

name: THIELLE (des bords de la)
notes: Confirmation: assumed to be Thielle. As river Thielle forms border, could equally be in Berne. There is also a Thielle river in the Vaud. For mapping and data analysis reasons, Neuchâtel sovereign territory is 'Neuchâtel' and not 'Prussia'.

name: PONT-DE-THIELLE
notes: Built to protect Neuchâtel side of bridge; building of canal in 1894 took it to Berne side and it was incorporated into the canton of Berne (Dictionnaire Historique de la Suisse). For mapping and data analysis reasons, Neuchâtel sovereign territory is 'Neuchâtel' and not 'Prussia'.

name: CLAIRA-EN-AGENAIS
notes: Confirmation: formerly known as Clairac-en-Agenais, Clairac was a Protestant town of 5,900 inhabitants in 1793. Nowhere called Claira has been identified in the region.

name: FRAMBOURG, LE
notes: Confirmation: described as 'lieu dit Le Frambourg'. A border post described by Robert Darnton.
